Recently, the MO Department of Elementary and Secondary Education has released information regarding the extension of the Summer Food Service Program (SFSP). This was the program that we used to offer meals during our extended COVID break from March through the end of school last year. With this extension, the District will be able to offer these meals again through December or until details change. This is for breakfast and lunch.

Starting on Tuesday, September 8th, Bloomfield R-14 School District will be offering breakfast and lunch to anyone under the age of 18, FREE OF CHARGE. Students in school will be seeing the same great meals as usual. Any other community members, 18 and UNDER, can also come to school to get meals between 7:30 and 8:10 am for breakfast and 10:30 am and 12:10 pm for lunch. If you are not a student and would like to participate, please contact the central office for details.Please contact your student's building principal if you have any questions.

post_text:
Happy American Education Week! We are so fortunate in this country to have great free public schools. As we go through this week, we will be sharing a few facts about the American education system:

1. The first schools in the 13 colonies opened in the 17th century. The Boston Latin School was the first public school opened in the United States, in 1635. To this day, it remains the nation’s oldest public school.

2. Early public schools in the United States did not focus on academics like math or reading. Instead they taught the virtues of family, religion, and community.

3. Girls were usually taught how to read but not how to write in early America.

4. By the mid-19th century, academics became the sole responsibility of public schools.
